conversation.content: Everyone's cards are out— wait, [deep pitch] hold on. We doing this the smart way or the stupid way?
Well, I've actually got, um, my phone calculator ready here. Look, if everyone just tells me what they ordered, I mean, I can have individual totals in two minutes— tax and tip included.
You're volunteering to math this nightmare? Brave.

Already started a list! Marcus, you had the steak frites at twenty-eight; Jenny, salmon at thirty-two. Just shout out your mains and I'll handle the mental gymnastics— easier than watching you all suffer.
The appetizers though. We shared those three platters—

Right, so, those were forty-two total, which is, er, three-fifty per person if we split evenly. Unless someone didn't touch the calamari? No judgment, honestly, but it helps the math if you speak up now.
But Lisa's— [anxious] she's vegetarian, um, and she didn't touch, like, half the appetizers...
Lisa! You know, you're down to just the bruschetta then, which is, uh, fourteen divided by... actually, six people had that one. That's two thirty-three each— I'm keeping track, don't worry.
How are you, I mean, doing this so fast? It's kind of, well, terrifying.

Restaurant trauma from college, basically— four years of these exact arguments, so, I built a system. See? Everyone's name, their items, shared costs calculated proportionally... it's actually really satisfying once you get the hang of it.
And the [shaky voice] wine situation? Because, um, I definitely had, you know, two glasses but Jake killed the rest of that bottle himself.
Jake had— [gasp loudly] five glasses?! Okay, that's seventy dollars of wine on his tab alone. The bottle was ninety, you had twenty worth, he gets the rest— this is exactly why I document everything.
You're literally saving us from killing each other.

Happy to help! I find that [overly polite] mathematical precision prevents those awkward "you owe me seven dollars" texts for the next three weeks. Plus, everyone feels heard when the split's actually fair, don't you think?
Shit. Actually, wait— I think, er, someone needs to check if, hmm, the automatic gratuity's already on there.

Already checked— no auto-grat! They only do that for parties of fifteen or more, so we need to add twenty percent ourselves. That's forty-nine dollars and change total, which splits to about four bucks each for tip.
Marcus is [stern] shaking his head. He's, well, definitely about to make this, you know, complicated again.

Marcus! Look, um, I've got your total at thirty-four even— that's including, honestly, your exact portion of appetizers minus the calamari you didn't touch. See the breakdown? Steak, bruschetta portion, tax, tip— completely transparent.
This is... actually, uh, incredible. You should, like, charge for this service or, I mean, something.
Just promise me we're using separate checks next time! My phone's at two percent battery and I can see Derek reaching for the dessert menu— absolutely not happening on my watch.
